ABSTRACT
Image fusion along time dimension is
investigated to explain aspects of multi-sensors
visual patterns and the related representation
tasks. We address image fusion problem by
describing a layered complex channels neural
model. In processing visual data conventionally
complex channels utilize both the linear and
nonlinear operations, and consist of two stages
filtering. The first filtering is sensitive to higher
spatial frequencies than the second, and they
suppose to explain a number of imagiag task
complexities that can not be explained by simple
channels.
The work reported here focuses on practical
applications and behavior modeling to examine
new perspectives for complex processes at the
sensory vision that begins with antagonistic
decomposition of input. lhis is then followed by
fusion of emergent time-sensitive dita to
promote a non-linear dynamic association. Our
reported result suggests that time fusion $of data
in multi-staged complex channels of neural
processes exhibit the true adaptive behavior that
adjust itself to a changing environment.

1. INTRODUCTION

According to the data in the literature, h i o n of

We explain imagefision process as a process to
acquire a higher qualified image that by
complementing local information componmts of
multiform p a t t e m . This is in effect an
extrapolation of the local information acquired
by various sensors performing over the exposure
time (t).
To clarify the ideas promoting image fusion, let
us first glance at few imaging samples. For
example, in remote sensing systems a wide
spectrum of data possibilities can be acquired
depending on the sensors are airborne or space
b e . In biomedical imaging, the magnetic
resonance imaging (MRI) and the computed
tomographic (cr) do not reveal identical details
of the brain tissues. This is while C T is suitable
for hard tissues the M R images are superior in
depicting the soft tissues in the brain. In either of
the above examples, different possibilities for
local data extraction arise from the different
imaging techniques that are complementary in
many ways but no one is sufficient in terms of
their local information content.
We may also refer to human vision, where
electrophysiologic, imaging, and biochemical
studies have provided us with much information
concerning the structural and functional
properties of visually responsive neurons and
their connections. However, crucial questions
concerning how local information for such
responsive cells are integrated (or fused), is still
unresolved. Another prime example relates to a
central issue in stereopsis that concerns the way
in which left and right eyes' views are fused to
solve the correspondence problem and recover
three dimensional scene structures.
There are numerous examples of the E n d and
the emerging superiority for fusion techniques to
render complemented images may appear partly
by redundant data as some regions are depicted
in all the possible image forms. Also partly by
complementary data as each different image
form highlight certain featnres that could be
absent in images of the other forms [Z].
Thus, in many applications the performances of
heterogeneous sensors are needed to provide the
additional source of information, where in such
cases data from an individual source are
incomplete. In this paper, we look at three
1819
different fusion applications to examine the
aspects of multiform images.
The first case relates to multi-frequency
fusion where data recorded by the same local
sensors operate in conditions with varying
frequency over the exposure time.
The second case relates to multi-data
fusion where data recorded by the same local
sensors operate in conditions with the scene
changes over the extent of exposure.
The third case relates to multi-images
fusion where data recorded by the same local
sensors operate in conditions with varying image
data over the exposure time.
The underlying idea for multi-sensors image
fusion is investigated within the fiamework of
biological-inspired complex channels neural
model. In all cases selected for our fusion
studies, we assume the multiform pattern fusion
is performed over the exposure time (t > 0). This
is performed by a grwp of fully interconnected
Sensors scanning a Limited window of a scene.
Thus, in this context fusion process extends from
zero exposure time, i.e., spatial image fusion
with t = 0, to the extended exposure time i.e.,
temporal image fusion with t > 0.

Section 3, we have a brief discussion on time

Conclusions are drawn in Section 5.
2. FUSION TECHNIQUES
In this section, our discussion centers on an
understanding of the underlying issues and
mechanisms for a self-adaptive scheme of image
fusion. The motivation behind the idea of
studying a self-adaptive fusion technique ensues
from its broad spectrum of engineering and
behavior modeling applications.
2.1. The Challenge
We choose to study a computational model to
reconstruct the basic processing phenomena
relating to human sensory vision. In the course
of this shldy, we assume that streams of image
data impinge the system sensors over the scene
exposure period The associated first challenge
to such a multifaceted imaging protocol,
however, relates to sensors interactions in space
and time, i.e., response is a function of sensors
position and time. The challenging task can he
put into perspective that given two spatial input
streams or patterns a") and a' " having general
form of a@) = (al(') ,aJk) ,. . . . . . . . . . . ., %(k) ) impinge
the same local sensory area in temporal
succession, then the question is how does the
vision system know that spatial pattern a(') is
being changed to a different succeeding pattern
a") [3]. Moreover, how does the system generate
responses to differentiate space and time
attributed data within the self-adaptive processes
of a human like vision system?
Thus, in relating to a self-adaptive multi-sensors
fusion system the first and the foremost
confronting challenge, however, relates to how
separate local regularities, i.e., i m g e pattem
modalities, are entwined Over space and time
without loss of structural integrity.
2.2. Structural & Time Constraints
In other words, we are looking at the
fundamental question of how space and time
interact over the exposure or fusion time to
determine the emergent properties of the higher
qualified fused image.
In general, time can be embedded in such a self-
adaptive system in two basic ways: structural
constraints, and the presentation
time
constraints. Structural constraints, may be
defined in terms of cam'ers regularities (or
background changes), syntactic regularities (or
pattem changes), and recurrent regularities (or
profile ordering changes). Presentation time
constraints relates to exposure duration [4],
which in a normal process control system can be
assumed to be directly linked to structural
complexities.
This implies that increase in structural
complexity changes is followed by increase in
presentation time. To study such an active
interposed relationship of input image time
components, we have developed a complex
channel neural model. The idea is to investigate a
new perspective for complex channels
processing [SI that by introducing a temporal
fusion mechanism. In essence, our multi-staged
processing begins with decomposition of sensory
streams impinging the local cell complexes in
the dual antagonistic pathways of a multi-layer
neural system.
In this system, responses of local cell complexes
in separated pathways are exclusively fused to

4. FUSION APPLICATIONSAND
SELECTED SAMPLES
Our method assumes neither prior preprocessing
knowledge nor any other insertion of data, which
may pre-mediate a self-organized fusion process.
According to the data in the literature (e.g. [9]),
to define self-organizing process, tlpee sub
processes-results in emergence of a self-
organized response map. This includes the
broadcasting of extemal events, the competition
among local stimulus-activated cells, and
adaptation in the neighborhood of competing
units, which seem to be sufficient.
